text:
Leicester and Leicestershire councils have no plan drawn up for 'no deal' Brexit 'There are so many exit strategies being discussed where would we start?' Leicester City Council has not drawn up a plan in case of a ‘no deal’ Brexit.
Local authorities across the country have put together reports and strategies to prepare for the repercussions if the UK leaves the EU without a deal.
A ‘no deal’ exit would see the UK and EU sever ties on March 29, 2019 with no agreement in place over what the future of our relationship with the EU will look like.
It would also mean there would be no transition period following the UK’s departure. What Sir Peter Soulsby says
City Mayor, Sir Peter Soulsby , has said it’s difficult to come up with a plan when the exit strategy remains uncertain.
He said: “Like the rest of the country we haven’t got a clue what we’re planning for and we can’t plan if we don’t know what we’re planning for.
“There are so many exit strategies being discussed where would we start?
“It’s an ever changing situation and it’s getting dangerously close.
“It’s looking frighteningly like we’ll just crash out.”
Later this month the government is planning to issue 70 technical notices advising businesses and consumers on how to prepare for a ‘no deal’. Read More
Sir Peter added: “I’ve enormous sympathy for the many local businesses who trade with the EU and they must be very worried about what faces them.
“Somehow or another as a council we will cope.
“The range of exit strategies is so great we really have very little option but to keep our fingers crossed and that is no way to plan for something of this scale.” What the county council says
Leicestershire County Council confirmed that as yet, it also does not have a 'no deal' plan.
A spokesperson explained: “We don’t have a plan at the moment, but we are assessing risks arising out of Brexit and we’re carefully monitoring the situation as it evolves.” What could happen if we get 'no deal' Brexit?
In the event of no deal being reached between the EU and the UK there would be immediate changes to border controls likely causing huge transport delays.
The rights of EU citizens in the UK and the other way round would be instantly impacted and the UK would have substantially less access to the EU single market.
It would likely result in a big jolt to the UK economy with the loss of jobs and falling GDP. The post-Brexit relationship would be governed by basic rules of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
As it stands, no other major trading partner of the EU trades with it on WTO terms alone. Problems and delays at ports could lead to issues with importing goods like foods and medicines. Health Secretary Matt Hancock has said that the NHS is stockpiling medicines in case a deal isn’t made. Like us on Facebook
